w:r.w:t: introduced to members of the family. They will learn how to discuss members of their own family by using the possessive pronoun
it is important for students to be able to talk about his/her personal family. Students will also be able to respond to questions about their family.

Recognize different family members and their roles
Various pictures of families, mom with child, dad with child, mom and dad together, mom, dad and child, child and sister, child and brother, mom, dad, sister, brother, and child.

-branded opener slide that the teacher will display as the student enters the classroom.

a mom, dad, sister, brother and me.”

Prompt the student by circling each member of the family asking: “Who is this?”
If the student is unsure teach the sentence: “It is a family.”

Student writes the word on the screen or a piece of paper.
Show various pictures of Moms with children.
show height, or act like holding a baby to show mom.
Ask: Who is this? Use TPR to shrug shoulders as in a question
by pointing toward yourself saying: “This is my mom.”
Student repeats: This is my mom.
Extension: If the student’s mother is nearby, encourage the student to point toward their mom by asking: “Where is your mom?” Using TPR to model looking for someone and point to the student for
Complete the sentence frame with the correct word:
Student repeats the word dad several times.
Clap as the student spells the word dad, student then claps.
Visual Cue: Show various pictures of Dads with children.
TPR show height, or act like holding a baby to show mom.
Ask: Who is this? Use TPR to shrug shoulders as in a question
by pointing toward yourself saying: “This is my dad.”
Student repeats: This is my dad.
Extension: If you know the student’s dad is present ask: “Where is your dad using TPR?” Student should respond by saying: “My dad is here,” or “This is my dad.”
Student draws a line between the words mom and dad and the appropriate pictures.
Model drawing a line on a white board or on the screen while asking the student to match.
mom and dad, or have them repeat word by word.
by holding things close to you saying “mine” and “my.” Say: “This is mine,” and then say: “This is my___.”
Ask: Who’s is this?” Make sure to shrug shoulders in a question.
Visual cue: Use a ball and banana to teach mine.
Ask: Who is this? Making sure to again shrug shoulders in a question.
If possible show a picture of you with your parents saying: “This is my dad,” and “This is my mom
” to teach possessive with family members.
Complete the sentence frame with the correct word:
“No, I do not have a sister.”
Student writes the word sister on the screen or piece of paper.
Visual cue: Teach sister by showing
student several pictures of sisters or a sister and brother.
Ask: Do you have a sister? Use TPR to indicate a question and point toward a picture of a sister.
Extension: If applicable use TPR to
as if their sister is older or younger by motioning tall and short. Ask age of sibling.
Complete the sentence frame with the correct word:
“No, I do not have a brother.”
Have the student repeat brother several times.
Student writes the word brother on the screen or piece of paper.
by showing student several pictures of
Ask: Do you have a brother? Use TPR to indicate a question and point toward a picture of a brother.
Extension: If applicable use TPR to
as if their brother is older or younger by motioning tall and short
Student draws a line between the words sister and brother and the appropriate pictures.
Model drawing a line on a white board or on the screen while asking the student to match.
Have student say: “This is sister,” after drawing the line.
If the student has trouble, review sister and brother, or have them repeat the sentence word by word.
Complete the sentence frame with the correct word:
Have the student repeat family several times.
Clap as the student spells the word out loud, have the student also clap as they spell the word the second time.
Review the word family by showing various pictures of families.
Ask: “Who is this?” Indicate a question by shrugging
Reads the words: “mom, dad, sister, brother, family.”
Model filling in the missing letter to a familiar word. Could also use “mine” to reinforce a word
Encourage student to read the words as they fill in the missing letters.
Circle each person on the screen asking: “Who is this?” Underline each word in the question as you ask it.
Student may respond with articles “a, the, or my,” all are grammatically correct.
After all individuals have been identified circle the entire family,
Student circles the image of the mom.
The student circles the correct image and responds: “This is mom.”
Extension- ask: “Who is this?” circling the teacher.
Re-teach mine and my using TPR to point to yourself
Ask: “Who is this,” while circling each image on the screen.
Student draws a line from the correct word to the correct picture.
Student says each word as they read it out loud.
Student creates a sentence with each word:
Model drawing lines from the correct picture to the correct word, choose one of the words or write one of your own.
Have the student say each word as they draw the line.
Have student respond in a complete sentence.
If they have trouble correct them and help guide toward the correct answer.
Freeform “Show and Tell” Conversation Activity Slide
“In my family there is my mom, dad, and me.”
Show pictures of your family, student may follow lead and show pictures of their family or show actual family members in the home.
Ask as many simple questions as possible to encourage student output.
